choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to an ophthalmologist with occasional headaches and no specific vision complaints. The examination reveals increased cupping of the optic disc, visual field defects, and elevated intraocular pressure. A diagnosis of primary open-angle glaucoma is made. Treatment is initiated with topical eye drops and regular follow-up visits are scheduled. The following finding is noticed on a follow-up visit. Which drug(s) is/are responsible for it?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Latanoprost

 

Explanation:

 

The given image shows Long, Thick Eyelashes which is a side-effect of Prostaglandin analogues.

 

Prostaglandin Analogues:

 

  • Latanoprost
  • Travoprost
  • Bimatoprost
  • Tafluprost

 

Side effects of Prostaglandin Analogues

 

  1. Conjunctival Hyperemia
  2. Eyelash Lengthening, Thickening, Hyperpigmentation
  3. Irreversible Iris Hyperpigmentation
  4. Reversible Hyperpigmentation of Periocular Skin
  5. Increased risk of Cystoid Macular Edema following Cataract Surgery

 

Educational objective:

 

A well-documented side effect of Prostaglandin Analogs, including Latanoprost, is increased Eyelash Growth, or Hypertrichosis.

 

Ref: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 8th Edition, Page 331

choices.text: 30 degrees
60 degrees
40 degrees

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a family history of glaucoma visits the ophthalmologist for a routine examination. Her IOP is measured, optic disc and angle of anterior chamber are examined. On gonioscopy, Schlemm’s canal, trabecular meshwork, scleral spur and ciliary body band are visible. What is the angle width?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 40 degrees

 

Option D:

 

  • As given in the diagram and table below, when all 4 structures are visible, the angle subtended is 40° indicating the patient has a wide open angle, with no chance of closure.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: In an angle with a width of 30 degrees, SL, TM, SS are the only angle structures seen.

 

Option B & C: 90 degree and 60 Degree configurations are not described for angle structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Based on the visibility of all the listed structures (Schlemm’s canal, trabecular meshwork, scleral spur, and ciliary body band), the correct answer is D. 40 degrees, indicating a wide-open angle.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th Edition, Page 220

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of Vogt's triad following an episode of acute primary angle closure glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Goniosynechiae

 

Option D.

 

  • Goniosynechiae refer to iridiotrabecular adhesions of the peripheral iris to the trabecular meshwork. It is not a part of Vogt’s triad.

 

 

  • Vogt’s triad is seen in both treated and untreated cases after an attack of acute PAC glaucoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Glaucomflecken (Anterior Subcapsular Lenticular Opacity). These are the small, white, opaque spots on the lens indicative of previous acute attacks.

 

 

Option B. Slightly dilated non-reacting pupil due to sphincter atrophy.

 

Option C. Patches of iris atrophy occurs due to ischemia from the prolonged contact between the iris and the trabecular meshwork.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The components of Vogt's triad for primary angle closure glaucoma include glaukomflecken, iris atrophy, and mid-dilated pupil.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th edition, page 245

choices.text: Primary Open Angle Glaucoma
Pseudo-Exfoliation Glaucoma
Acute Angle Closure Attack
Primary Angle Closure Glaucoma

questions.text: A 40-year-old male came to the OPD with complaints of sudden onset Severe Pain in Right Eye since morning. Examination showed Circumcorneal Congestion & Shallow Anterior Chamber. What is the probable Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute Angle Closure Attack

 

Option C:

 

  • Acute Angle Closure Glaucoma occurs when there is a relatively sudden blockage of the trabecular meshwork leading to obstruction in Aqueous Humor outflow and consequently causing elevation of the Intraocular Pressure.
  • One possible mechanism is the Anterior Bulging of the Peripheral Iris, occluding the Trabecular Meshwork and trapping Aqueous Humor.
  • The reason for the sudden Anterior Bulging of the Peripheral Iris may be due to Pupillary Block (where the lens presses up against the iris trapping all the Aqueous Humor behind it).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Primary open-angle glaucoma: Insidious onset and usually asymptomatic initially with mild headache and ocular pain. May have history of frequent change in near vision glasses.

 

Option B. Pseudo-Exfoliation Glaucoma: Amorphous grey dandruff-like material deposition on pupillary border, anterior lens surface, posterior iris surface, zonules, ciliary process and blockage of trabecular meshwork with the same. Clinically usually behaves like POAG, but can present as ACG also.

 

Option D. Primary Angle Closure Glaucoma: Can present with intermittent symptoms of Blurring and Haloes due to Corneal Epithelial Oedema or acutely with markedly Decreased Vision and Ocular/Periocular Pain and Headache (like in the question, for which a more suitable answer is Acute Angle Closure Attack).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the classic presentation of an Acute Angle-Closure Attack, which includes sudden onset of severe Ocular Pain, Circumcorneal Congestion, and a shallow Anterior Chamber, requiring prompt recognition and management.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th Edition, Page 244

choices.text: Reduces Aqueous Production
Increases Trabecular Outflow
Increases Uveoscleral Outflow
All of the above

questions.text: A 65-year-old female with a family history of glaucoma undergoes a routine eye examination. She is asymptomatic but on examination it seen that her intraocular pressure is raised, and further evaluation reveals early-stage optic nerve damage. She is diagnosed with primary open angle glaucoma and is given a beta-blocker. What is the mode of action of beta-blockers?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reduces Aqueous Production.

 

Option A: Beta-blockers:

 

  • Mode of Action: Reduce IOP by Reducing Aqueous production by effect on Ciliary Epithelium.
  • Contraindications:
  • Asthma
  • Cardiovascular disease
  • Peripheral vascular disease
  • Instillation as bedtime: (not to be done) as this medication may cause a significant drop in BP while the individual is asleep, thus reducing optic disc perfusion and potentially causing visual field deterioration.
  • Agents:
  • Timolol
  • Betaxolol (relatively cardioselective)
  • Levobunolol
  • Carteolol

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Increases Trabecular Outflow is not the primary action of beta-blockers. Drugs that increase trabecular outflow are typically prostaglandin analogs or cholinergic agents, not beta-blockers.

 

Option C. Like increasing trabecular outflow, this is not a mechanism of action for beta-blockers. Increasing uveoscleral outflow is a mechanism associated with prostaglandin analogs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta Blockers reduce intraocular pressure by reducing aqueous production in the eye.

 

Ref: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 8th Edition, Page 331

choices.text: Laser Iridotomy

questions.text: A 42-year-old female patient diagnosed with angle closure glaucoma in right eye is planned for a prophylactic procedure in the left eye. The procedure is done and post-op eye is shown below. What is the prophylactic measure taken in this eye?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laser Iridotomy

 

Option C:

 

In this image, note the circular opening at 9’0 Clock. This is the site of iridotomy.

 

  • In primary angle closure glaucoma, there is appositional closure of angle of anterior chamber.
  • This leads to accumulation of aqueous humour in the posterior chamber and consequently leads to anterior bowing of iris.
  • Treatment: Laser iridotomy is done along with medical therapy.
  • Prophylactic Laser iridotomy is done in the other eye.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Goniotomy is a surgical procedure done to create an opening in the trabecular meshwork. It can be done by two approaches, ab-interno and ab-externo.

 

 

Option B: Iridectomy is a procedure in which a section of the iris is incised through a scleral or limbal incision. It is a part of trabeculectomy surgery. Additionally, prophylactic surgical iridectomy is done in cases where there is a chance of postoperative pupillary block glaucoma, such as in cases of uveitis, in cases with silicone oil injection or air/gas injection in eye.

 

 

Option D: Trabeculectomy – It is a glaucoma surgery where a subconjunctival filtering bleb is created via a scleral flap to drain intraocular aqueous and reduce intraocular pressure, bypassing the trabecular meshwork.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A well circumscribed opening in the midperipheral iris is suggestive of iridotomy.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th edition, page 249

choices.text: Both A & B

questions.text: A 63-year-old female who presented to the ophthalmologist with acute onset of severe pain and diminution of vision in the left eye was diagnosed with angle closure glaucoma. She was given medications to control her IOP and was posted for Laser peripheral iridotomy. Which laser will be used for this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both A & B

 

Option D:

 

  • Laser Peripheral Iridotomy requires Argon or Nd:YAG laser.
  • It is done if Peripheral Anterior Synechiae (PAS) is more than 270 degrees of angle. Done at mid-peripheral iris 1 or 11 o’clock position.
  • Establishes communication between anterior & posterior chamber.
  • So, it bypasses the pupillary block & relieves crowding of angle.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option C: Krypton Red laser was historically used for retinal photocoagulation. Not very commonly used now.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For peripheral iridotomy, both Argon and Nd:YAG laser are used.

 

Ref: Comprehensive Ophthalmology, A K Khurana, 5th Edition, Page 245

questions.text: A patient underwent prophylactic Nd:YAG peripheral iridotomy. Which of the following agents is prescribed to counter post procedure spike in IOP?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Apraclonidine

 

Option C. Apraclonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that decreases IOP by reducing aqueous humor production and increasing uveoscleral outflow. It is often used specifically to prevent or treat spikes in IOP after laser eye surgery, making it an appropriate choice in this context. It has a rapid onset of action, which is beneficial for acute management post-procedure.

 

EXPLANATION:

 

Option A. Timolol is a beta-blocker used topically in the eye to reduce IOP by decreasing the production of aqueous humor by the ciliary body. It is effective in managing chronic open-angle glaucoma and can be used to control IOP spikes. However, it might not be the first choice immediately post-laser procedures due to its mechanism of action and time to onset.

 

Option B. Dorzolamide is a topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that reduces IOP by decreasing the production of aqueous humor in the eye. Like Timolol, it is used in the treatment of open-angle glaucoma and ocular hypertension. While effective, its mechanism also involves a decrease in aqueous production, and there might be more immediate and effective options for acute IOP spikes post-laser procedures.

 

Option D. Pilocarpine is a cholinergic agonist that works by constricting the pupil and pulling the iris away from the trabecular meshwork, increasing the outflow of aqueous humor and thus lowering IOP. It is used in the management of angle-closure glaucoma. However, in the context of post-iridotomy care, its use might be less relevant since the iridotomy itself is intended to relieve pupillary block, and further constriction of the pupil might not be necessary or beneficial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the management of a post-procedure spike in intraocular pressure (IOP) following prophylactic Nd:YAG peripheral iridotomy, Apraclonidine is prescribed due to its rapid onset and effectiveness in reducing IOP by decreasing aqueous humor production and increasing uveoscleral outflow

 

Ref: PARSONS DISEASES OF EYE 22ND EDITION PAGE 157

questions.text: A 55-year-old asthmatic male presents to an ophthalmology clinic with complaints of gradual vision loss and occasional headaches. Examination reveals optic nerve damage and visual field defects consistent with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG). Intraocular pressure is elevated, and the patient's cup-to-disc ratio is increased. The first line management for POAG is medical, by drugs that lower intraocular pressure. All of the following can be prescribed to him, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Timolol

 

Option B: Common side effects of beta blockers are dry eye, bradycardia, bronchial spasms, depression, and fatigue.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Brinzolamide is a topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used in the treatment of glaucoma. It works by decreasing the production of aqueous humour in the eye. It does not typically exacerbate bronchial asthma and is generally considered safe for use in patients with this condition.

 

Option C. Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analogue, another class of medications used to treat glaucoma. It works by increasing the outflow of aqueous humour from the eye. Prostaglandin analogues are not known to adversely affect asthma and are generally safe for asthmatic patients.

 

Option D. Dorzolamide, similar to brinzolamide, dorzolamide is a topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and is considered safe for use in patients with bronchial asthma as it typically does not exacerbate the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systemic absorption of Timolol can potentially affect the respiratory system, and it can exacerbate bronchial asthma by causing bronchoconstriction. Beta-blockers are generally contraindicated in patients with asthma due to this risk.

 

Ref: Parsons Diseases of Eye 22nd Edition Page: 157

questions.text: A 52-year-old female had gone for a movie when she started to complaint of a sudden onset of severe pain in her right eye for which she immediately came to the ophthalmologist. On taking history, it is learnt that she has no co-morbidities and is allergic to sulfa drugs. On examination, a congested conjunctiva is noticed with shallow AC, closed angle and very high IOP. A diagnosis of acute congestive glaucoma is made. Which of the following drugs needs to be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acetazolamide

 

Option D:

 

  • Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor for systemic use.
  • Sulfonamide (‘sulfa’) allergy is a relative contraindication of this group of drugs.
  • Some of the important sulfa drugs:
    • Probenecid
    • Celecoxib
    • Furosemide
    • Acetazolamide
    • Sulfonamide antibiotics
    • Sulfasalazine
    • Sulfonylureas
    • Thiazides

 

Mnemonic: “Please cfast”

 

Side Effects:

 

  • Paraesthesia (‘Pins and Needles’ sensation in the extremities)
  • Hypokalemia
  • Malaise and Lowered Mood
  • Gastrointestinal Symptoms
  • Renal Stones
  • Dose-Related Bone Marrow Suppression
  • Idiosyncratic Aplastic Anaemia

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic commonly used to reduce intraocular pressure in glaucoma or to reduce intracranial pressure. It does not contain sulfa and is generally safe for patients with sulfa allergies.

 

Option B. Prostaglandin (PG) Analogues are used in the treatment of glaucoma and work by increasing uveoscleral outflow to lower intraocular pressure. Prostaglandin analogues do not contain sulfa and are typically safe for patients with sulfa allergies.

 

Option C. Glycerol (or glycerine) is an osmotic agent used to lower intraocular pressure. It does not contain sulfa and is safe for patients with sulfa allergies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acetazolamide, as it is a sulfa-based medication and can cause allergic reactions in patients with sulfa allergies.

 

Ref: Kanski 9TH Edition Page 407

questions.text: A patient underwent prophylactic Nd:YAG peripheral iridotomy. All of the following agents is prescribed to counter post procedure spike in IOP, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pilocarpine

 

Option D: Pilocarpine, a cholinergic agonist, works by constricting the pupil and pulling the iris away from the trabecular meshwork, thus increasing aqueous humor outflow. However, in the context of post-iridotomy care, pilocarpine is the exception. The purpose of an iridotomy is to create an opening in the iris to relieve pupillary block and facilitate aqueous humor flow, rendering the action of pilocarpine (which aims to achieve a similar outcome through miosis) less relevant or even counterproductive post-iridotomy. The iridotomy itself should alleviate the mechanism that pilocarpine targets, and additional constriction of the pupil may not be beneficial.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Timolol as a beta-blocker, Timolol decreases aqueous humor production, thus lowering IOP. It is commonly used in glaucoma management, including after laser procedures, to control IOP.

 

Option B. Dorzolamide, topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor reduces IOP by decreasing aqueous humor production. It is also used in glaucoma management and can be used post-laser procedures to control IOP spikes.

 

Option C. Apraclonidine, an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that reduces IOP by decreasing aqueous humor production and increasing uveoscleral outflow. It is specifically used to prevent or treat spikes in IOP after laser eye surgery, making it highly relevant in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pilocarpine is the exception, as it is less likely to be prescribed post Nd:YAG peripheral iridotomy to counter a spike in IOP, given that the procedure itself addresses the issue pilocarpine is used to manage.

 

Ref: PARSONS DISEASES OF EYE 22ND EDITION PAGE 157
